intro: Papaver rhoeas subsp. cyprium, commonly known as the Cyprus poppy, is a subspecies of the common poppy characterized by its striking red petals and a distinctive, bulbous seed capsule. It is native to the Mediterranean region, particularly Cyprus, and thrives in well-drained soils. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring alternate, lance-shaped leaves and showy flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its botanical features make it a valuable species for both ornamental gardening and ecological studies. The subspecies is notable for its resilience and ability to adapt to various environmental conditions.
